questions.text: A 22-day-old baby presenting with seizures, increased head size over the past week, and a sunset sign in the eyes, what is the most common cause of this condition?

A 29-year-old female presenting with generalized weakness and decreased sensations on the left side of her body, the Neurology OPD examination involves rubbing a wisp of cotton on her fingertip with closed eyes. What sensory function does this test assess, and what is the underlying mediation?

A 9-month-old girl is admitted to the hospital with tachypnea and shortness of breath. On physical examination, there is tachycardia and a bounding peripheral pulse, and her angiograms show a patent ductus arteriosus. Which of the following embryonic arterial structures is responsible for developing the ductus arteriosus ?
questions.explanation:
Aortic arch vascular derivatives

Aortic arch

Adult derivative

First

  • Part of maxillary artery

Second

  • Hyoid artery
  • Stapedial artery

Third

  • Common carotid artery
  • Proximal internal carotid artery

Fourth

  • On left → aortic arch
  • On right → proximal right subclavian artery

Sixth

  • Proximal pulmonary arteries
  • On left → ductus arteriosus

questions.text: In a 43-year-old female with lower extremity edema, abdominal pain, early satiety, and weight loss, due to a retroperitoneal mass compressing and obstructing the IVC, which structure is not involved in collateral blood supply?

options.label: A
options.text: Superior epigastric and inferior epigastric vein

questions.correct_answer: B. Superficial epigastric and iliolumbar vein

questions.text: A 47-year-old tennis player comes to the office to evaluate shoulder pain during training. The doctor tells her that she has a rotator cuff injury that needs surgery. The doctor explains that over the years of play, a shoulder ligament gradually damaged the muscle underneath badly. Which of the following ligaments is the doctor most likely referring to?

Which muscle is most likely affected in a 45-year-old male who sustained multiple lacerations to the upper limb after walking through a plate glass door while intoxicated, resulting in an inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joints of the second and fifth digits?

A 60-year-old male presents to the liver center with jaundice and generalized edema. After a thorough assessment, a diagnosis of cryptogenic cirrhosis is made. A liver transplant is planne d . During the operation, the transplant doctor asks his junior residents a bout the anatomy of the liver. Which of the following statements is true about the anatomy and functions of the liver?

options.label: A
options.text: Receives blood only from the hepatic arteries

options.label: B
options.text: Manufactures red blood cells in an adult

options.label: C
options.text: Drains bile from the quadrate lobe into the right hepatic duct

options.label: D
options.text: Drains venous blood into the hepatic veins

questions.correct_answer: D. Drains venous blood into the hepatic veins

questions.text: A 29-year-old female presents in the clinic with complaints of abdominal bloating, pain, and nausea for the last 2 weeks. She also reports food intolerance. On detailed evaluation by MRCP, she is diagnosed with a pancreatic divisum. The term indicates:

options.label: B
options.text: Failure of fusion of dorsal & ventral pancreatic buds

options.label: C
options.text: Formation of more than two pancreatic buds

options.label: D
options.text: Formation of only one pancreatic bud

questions.correct_answer: B. Failure of fusion of dorsal & ventral pancreatic buds

questions.text: A primigravida at 40 weeks of gestation presents with labour pains for half an hour. During a spontaneous vaginal delivery complicated by obstructed labour, an episiotomy is performed, and forceps are used. Examination reveals a second-degree tear involving a crack in the upper boundary of the superficial perineal space . Which structure is likely damaged?
Which of the following structures forms the posterior boundary of the carotid triangle?

A 62-year-old woman presented with involuntary rhythmic movements of her hands for the past 3 months, worse at rest and affecting both hands, with a history of chronic liver disease, hypertension, and peripheral artery disease. W hat is the most likely diagnosis based on examination findings and the structure involved in the patient's pathology, as shown in the provided image?

For a 2-week-old girl with a mass on her lower back since birth, born full-term without prenatal care. On examination, a non-tender mass, covered by skin, is present on the lower back above the gluteal crease. What course of treatment is recommended after a detailed workup?
questions.correct_answer: B. Surgical removal by age 6 months

questions.text: A 27-year-old rugby player sustained a fracture to the right tibia after a collision injury. After his lower leg had been in a cast for 8 weeks, he found that the right gastrocnemius muscle was significantly smaller in circumference than it was before the fracture. This is due to:

options.label: A
options.text: Decrease in the number of individual muscle fibers in the muscle.

options.label: B
options.text: Decrease in blood flow to the muscle caused by constriction from the cast.

options.label: C
options.text: Temporary reduction in actin and myosin protein synthesis.

questions.correct_answer: C. Temporary reduction in actin and myosin protein synthesis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male was brought to the emergency day after a road traffic accident 20 minutes ago. He has multiple lacerations to his upper extremities and sustained an open fracture to his lower extremity. Initial CBC reveals white blood cells count at 22 x 10 3 /µl, and subsequent complete blood count analysis after 5 hours reveals the white blood cells count at 7 x 10 3 /µl . Which of the following is the r eason for the increase in white blood cell count on the initial blood report?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased production of WBCs by the bone marrow

options.label: B
options.text: Release of pre-formed, mature WBCs into the circulation

questions.correct_answer: B. Release of pre-formed, mature WBCs into the circulation

questions.text: During which phase of the cardiac cycle is the second heart sound (S2) generated?
questions.explanation:
Sound   Associated Events
S1 First heart sound (sounds like lub) Closure of mitral and tricuspid valves
  Two bursts, a mitral M1 and a tricuspid T1 component  
S2

Second heart sound (sounds like dub)

An aortic A2 and a pulmonary P2 component

 Closure of aortic and pulmonary valves
OS Opening snap Opening of a stenotic mitral valve
S3 Third heat sound Diastolic filling gallop or ventricular or protodiastolic gallop
S4 Fourth heart sound The atrial sound that creates an atrial or presystolic gallop

questions.text: N 2 washout (or Fowler's method) - A subject takes a breath of 100% O 2 and exhales through a one-way valve measuring nitrogen content and volume. A plot of the N 2 concentration (as a % of total gas) vs expired volume is obtained by increasing the N 2 concentration from zero to the percentage of N 2 in the alveoli. Fowler's method is employed for the measurement of which of the following parameter?

A professor teaches first-year medical students about glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and the properties of a substance used to measure GFR. In addition to the requirement that it be freely filtered and neither reabsorbed nor secreted in the tubules, a substance suitable for measuring the GFR should be non-toxic and not metabolized by the body. Which of the following will most likely decrease GFR by more than 10% in a normal kidney?

options.label: A
options.text: Decrease in renal arterial pressure from 100 to 85 mm Hg

options.label: D
options.text: 50% increase in the glomerular capillary filtration coefficient

questions.correct_answer: C. 50% decrease in efferent arteriolar resistance

questions.text: RIA is very sensitive in vitro assay technique used to measure concentrations of substances, usually measuring antigen concentrations (for example, hormone levels in the blood) by use of antibodies. If a radioimmunoassay is properly conducted and the amount of radioactive hormone bound to the antibody is low, what would this result indicate?

options.label: A
options.text: Plasma levels of endogenous hormone are high

options.label: B
options.text: Plasma levels of endogenous hormone are low

questions.correct_answer: A. Plasma levels of endogenous hormone are high

questions.text: Which of the following cell types is mainly responsible for preventing the drug from reaching the CNS?
Which system has the best degree of temporal and spatial fidelity in transmitting somatosensory information?
Through which of the following layers does the light enter the retina ?

A neuron, the functional unit of the nervous system, is responsible for initiating and propagating nerve impulses. The axon's initial segment, just between the peak of the axon hillock and the initial (unmyelinated) segment, is also known as the trigger zone for the action potential. Which following is responsible for initiating a nerve impulse at the axon's initial segment?

options.label: A
options.text: It has a lower threshold than the rest of the axon

questions.correct_answer: A. It has a lower threshold than the rest of the axon

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for producing dicrotic notc h on the arterial pulse waveform?
questions.correct_answer: B. Closure of the semilunar valves

questions.text: An investigator is studying the different reflexes involved in the physiology of the respiratory system. He finds that in a newborn, the inflation of the lungs sends a signal to the respiratory centre in the medulla that causes further distention of the lung. This reflex is seen most often on the first day and may act as a way to establish and maintain a functional residual capacity. Which of the following reflex is being observed by the investigator?

A 6-year-old boy experienced episodes of generalized skin rash, particularly in sun-exposed areas , and resolution within a week to 10 days. The pediatrician prescribed niacin and a high-protein diet, resulting in the rash resolving within a day or two during subsequent occurrences. What could be the likely diagnosis?

An obese young woman accidentally ingests a banned drug and develops a high-grade fever . It was once known to be used for weight reduction. The drug is known to affect ATP formation in the Electron Transport Chain. What could be that drug?

A 40-year-old woman with recurrent hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, growth retardation, and polyuria is found to have elevated glycogen levels in the liver and kidney. Further investigation reveals a mutation in the GLUT-2 transporter. Which of the following diseases is most likely associated with this GLUT-2 mutation?

A 28-year-old man presented to the hospital complaining of intractable vomiting and inability to eat or drink for the past 3 days. His blood analysis still shows a normal glucose level. Which of the following processes is mainly responsible for the blood glucose maintenance in this patient?

A 4-year-old male child is brought to the emergency room by his parents with rapid breathing. He was cold, clammy, confused, and lethargic. His mother gave a history of accidental ingestion of automobile antifreeze. Ethanol is used as a treatment for this poisoning because:

options.label: C
options.text: Inhibit binding of ethylene glycol to alcohol dehydrogenase

options.label: D
options.text: Stimulate the excretion of ethylene glycol

questions.correct_answer: C. Inhibit binding of ethylene glycol to alcohol dehydrogenase

questions.text: A 20-month-old male infant presented with developmental delay, seizures, and eczema. His urine has a characteristic tom cat urine smell, and blood analysis indicated organic acidemia. The patient is advised to take biotin supplementation to treat which of the following condition?

A 23-year-old tall male has feminine characteristics such as sparse facial hair, small testes, and gynecomastia. He also had poor coordination, language, and reading difficulties. Which of the following test is used to confirm this diagnosis ?
What role do small nuclear ribonucleoprotein particles (snRNPs) , the complexes formed by RNA and nucleoproteins, play in the process of splicing?

options.label: B
options.text: Facilitate the looping of the two exons into the correct alignment for splicing

options.label: D
options.text: snRNP assembly is affected in spinal muscular atrophy

questions.text: Which one of the following is a symptom of ammonia intoxication?

A 28-year-old male athlete training for a marathon race is advised by his coach to increase his carbohydrate intake after the workout. The carbohydrate uptake will help to build up glycogen stores in the muscles. Glycogen synthase is the main enzyme involved in glycogen synthesis in the muscles. Which of the following acts as an activator of muscle glycogen synthase?

A 23-year-old male athlete presents to the emergency with a history of chest discomfort. He says that he developed the condition while practicing for his upcoming marathon . The pain is relieved after a few minutes of rest. Which of the following represents the cell injury in this scenario ?

options.label: A
options.text: Detachment of ribosomes from the endoplasmic reticulum (ER)

questions.correct_answer: A. Detachment of ribosomes from the endoplasmic reticulum (ER)

questions.text: A 43-year-old man complains of a 1-week history of abdominal pain and yellow discolouration of his sclera. Physical examination shows right upper quadrant pain. Laboratory studies show increased serum levels of alkaline phosphatase (520 U/dL) and bilirubin (3.0 mg/dL). A liver biopsy reveals portal fibrosis, with scattered foreign bodies consistent with schistosome eggs. Which of the following inflammatory cells is most commonly to predominate in the portal tracts in the liver of this patient?

A 76-year-old female complains of chest pain, fever and productive cough with rust-coloured sputum. A chest X-ray reveals an infiltrate in the right middle lobe. Sputum cultures are positive for Streptococcus pneumoniae. Phagocytic cells in affected lung tissue generate bactericidal hypochlorous acid using the following enzymes ?

A 27-year-old female presents with a 1-week history of febrile illness and chest pain . She has an erythematous, macular facial rash and tender joints , particularly in her left wrist and elbow. A complete blood count shows mild anaemia and decreased platelet count . She also has increased serum levels of ceruloplasmin, fibrinogen, α2-macroglobulin, serum amyloid A protein, and C-reactive protein . All these markers belong to which of the following families of proteins?

A 57-year-old male presents to the surgical clinic complaining of swelling over the scalp region, which gradually developed over 6 months. He now complains of pus discharge several times in the past month, associated with pain. On examination, swelling sized 3x2 cm, Firm, Fixed; Tenderness(+), Warmth(+), Punctum(+), Discharge(+). Incision & Drainage is done, and the wound is left open to heal. Which of the following is a mechanism for healing in this case ?

A 42-year-old woman came with complaints of swallowing difficulties, dysarthria, fluctuating limb muscle weakness, and bilateral eyelid ptosis with incomplete occlusion. the symptoms decreased with rest and sleep. On examination, there was asymmetrical bilateral eyelid ptosis, unequal palpebral fissures with incomplete occlusion, limitation of facial movements and dysphagia. A neostigmine test was done with the improvement of symptoms post-injection. Which of the following is involved in the pathogenesis of the disease described here?

A 37-year-old woman presented to the physician's office complaining of progressive generalised weakness as the day progressed. On physical examination, she had drooping of the eyelids bilaterally and proximal muscle weakness in the shoulders and hips. After laboratory testing, she was found to have antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (AChR). Which of the following is most commonly associated with this disease?

A 20-year-old female patient was brought by her mother with a crown fracture of maxillary central incisors due to a fall 2 hours back. She has been mentally disabled since birth. She is morbidly obese and has narrow shoulders. Further tests reveal maternal disomy of chromosome 15. What is the cause of obesity in the given disease?

A 12-year-old girl child with a known case of sickle cell disease came for a blood transfusion. Her history is significant for recurrent childhood infections and acute chest syndrome. Her father also has sickle cell trait, and her mother has inflammatory bowel disease. On examination, swelling of fingers was noted, as shown in the picture below. She also reports she marked pain in her hands and feet. In sickle cell disease, which of the following does not influence the degree of sickling of red cells ?

A five-year-old boy is brought to your clinic by his mother with complaints of fever and fatigue . His mother states that he frequently gets ill. The patient's fever is associated with joint pain. The patient's examination findings are positive for hepatosplenomegaly and lymph node enlargement . Further investigations reveal a diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukaemia . The blast cells are positive for the cell marker CD95 . CD95 is an important cell marked for which of the following processes?

A 56-year-old postmenopausal female presents to the gynaecological outpatient department due to painful and heavy menstrual bleeding for the past 3 days. Her last menstrual period (LMP) was 10 years ago. Examination reveals a non-bloody vaginal discharge. An endometrial biopsy reveals atypical cells. Which of the following is not associated with the patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The process occurs in labile cells

options.label: B
options.text: There is an increase in the number of cells.

options.label: C
options.text: The risk of malignancy is present in certain cases.

options.label: D
options.text: Bone marrow cannot undergo this process.

questions.correct_answer: D. Bone marrow cannot undergo this process.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of easy bruising and fatigue. She appears pale. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Examination shows a palm-sized hematoma on her left leg. Abdominal examination shows an enlarged liver and spleen. Her haemoglobin concentration is 9.5 g/dL, her leukocyte count is 12,300/mm 3 , her platelet count is 55,000/mm 3 , and her fibrinogen concentration is 120 mg/dL. Cytogenetic analysis of leukocytes shows a reciprocal translocation of chromosomes 15 and 17. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old male presents to the outpatient department due to fatigue on exertion for 2 weeks. He has no other associated symptoms and no medical disorder history. His recent laboratory investigations are as follows: Hb 10.6g/dl MCV 92fL Neutrophils 1.3x10 3 /microliter Platelets 117x10 9 /microliter Creatinine 0.9mg/dl Serum calcium 11.2mg/dl Serum albumin 3.8mg/dl A skeletal examination reveals occult lytic lesions in the skull and bilateral humeri. A serum protein electrophoresis reveals elevated levels of monoclonal Ig A protein. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 15-year-old boy presents with significant sudden right-sided flank pain that started after he assisted his father in painting his bedroom ceiling this morning. On physical examination, his vitals are normal, but there is an ecchymosis in the right flank that is painful to touch . He has always been prone to bruising. His brother also has the same issue. His workup shows that clotting factor VIII levels in the blood are less than 2% normal . Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's bleeding tendency?

options.label: A
options.text: Circulating antibodies directed against factor VIII

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased hepatic synthesis of multiple coagulation factors

options.label: D
options.text: Genetic defect involving the factor VIII gene

questions.correct_answer: D. Genetic defect involving the factor VIII gene

questions.text: Following a car accident, a 19-year-old boy is transported to the emergency room in shock. He receives 5 units of blood transfusion . The patient experiences fever, nausea, vomiting, and chest pain after the transfusion. Indirect serum bilirubin is high, serum haptoglobin is decreased, and the Coombs test is positive. Which of the following diagnoses is the most likely?

A 69-year-old man visits the clinic with a complaint of vague abdominal distress for the last few weeks. The patient's weight has been stable. He has a history of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis and has been taking medications to provide symptomatic relief. The gastric lesion shown in the figure is resected following initial endoscopic discovery. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 33-year-old man arrives in the ER in an altered state after a suicide attempt with medication. He's dizzy, slurring his words and has low blood pressure. The doctor plans to start alkaline diuresis . What caused his condition?

A 49-year-old male presents with diplopia, slurred speech, breathing difficulty, drooping eyelids, and fatigue for 2 weeks , worsening progressively throughout the day and improving with rest. No other abnormalities or chronic illnesses reported. Vital signs stable, with no other physical abnormalities. Doctor prescribed neostigmine over physostigmine. What justifies this drug preference?

options.label: B
options.text: It has a longer duration of action

options.label: C
options.text: It doesn't cross BBB effectively and has no central action

questions.correct_answer: C. It doesn't cross BBB effectively and has no central action

questions.text: A 38-year-old female in the emergency department presents with weakness, sudden palpitations, sweating, and reduced urine output. Her vital signs include a temperature of 37.7°C, respiratory rate of 24 cycles/minute, and blood pressure of 88/64 mmHg . W ith a history of myocardial infarction, she's administered dopamine infusion. Why choose dopamine over dobutamine in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: It has additional renal vasodilatory effect

questions.correct_answer: A. It has additional renal vasodilatory effect

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presents with fever, anuria, nausea, and lethargy . On examination, the patient has a temperature of 40°C, respiratory rate of 22 breaths/min, blood pressure of 94/66 mmHg , and heart rate of 104 beats/min. His ECG reveals tall T waves. His serum electrolytes reveal Na+ 140 mmol/L, K+ 6.0 mmol/L, Cl-100 mmol/L, and HCO3- 24 mmol/L . Which of the following will be used for the management of this condition?

A 44-year-old male comes to your clinic with complaints of excessive thirst and excessive urination in the past 2-3 months. The patient sought a consultation since he had two episodes of bedwetting in the past week. On examination, you noticed that the patient had dry skin and also complained of mild constipation. You order fasting, random blood sugar, and an ultrasound of kidney, ureters, and, bladder (KUB), all of which turn out to be normal . Urinary and serum osmolality is consistent with diabetes insipidus . What would be the rationale for opting intranasal desmopressin spray over vasopressin?

options.label: A
options.text: It causes less formation of factor VIII

options.label: C
options.text: It is more selective for the V2 receptor subtype

options.label: D
options.text: Provides greater relief of excessive thirst the patient is experiencing

questions.correct_answer: C. It is more selective for the V2 receptor subtype
questions.explanation:
Similarities

                       Differences
  • Factor VIII and vWF release
  • Hyponatremia
  • Similar relief of excessive thirst
  • V2 receptor selectivity of desmopressin
  • V1 and V2 receptors of vasopressin
  • Vasopressin causes vasoconstriction, while desmopressin does not.

questions.text: A 44-year-old female presents to the emergency with complaints of difficulty in breathing. She reports no associated cough or fever. On examination, her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), her pulse is 120/min, her respiration rate is 28/min, and her blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. There are scattered wheezes on pulmonary examination. A chest x-ray is shown below: Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A 20-year-old foreigner, who had recently come to India for vacation, comes to the emergency with complaints of acute, multiple episodes of loose bowel movement for the last few days and informs that he is a diagnosed case of Ulcerative colitis. On physical examination, he has tachycardia and is mildly febrile. Which of the following medications would be appropriate for this patient?

A 43-year-old male presented in the OPD with complaints of excessive thirst. He also reports has polyuria and polyphagia. He suspects it could be diabetes mellitus and orders fasting blood sugar, postprandial blood sugar & HbA1c. The HbA1c was about 12% , and the blood sugar values were over 240. He decides to start the patient on subcutaneous insulin therapy and educate the patient regarding the same. What is the mechanism of action of the therapy prescribed?

A 44-year-old man comes to the clinic with tremors in his hand. Cogwheel rigidity is seen in the arm. Which antiparkinsonian drug works by directly activating dopaminergic D2 receptors in the striatum?

What treatment is recommended for a 45-year-old male with schizophrenia who developed fever, diarrhea, confusion, high blood pressure, rapid pulse, muscle rigidity, hyperkalemia, and increased creatine kinase after 8 days of haloperidol treatment?

An investigator develops a new drug used to treat arrhythmias. Before this d rug is tested in humans, it is tested in animals. This is known as a preclinical study and is considered mandatory. To study sub-acute toxicities , the drug is given to animals fo r how much time ?
questions.explanation:
PRECLINICAL TOXICITY STUDIES

Acute toxicity studies
  • Single escalating doses are given to a small group of animals, and the animals are observed for 1-3 days.
  • LD50 is calculated.
  • Organ toxicity is examined by histopathology.

Sub-acute toxicity studies
  • Repeated doses of the drug are given for 2-12 weeks.
  • Animals are examined for overt effects, food intake, body weight, and haematology.

Chronic toxicity studies
  • The drug is given for 6-12 months.
  • Animals are examined for overt effects, food intake, body weight, and haematology.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should be avoided in a patient with variant angina ?

A 2-year-old baby is brought to the hospital by his mother ,who is complaining of a large portion of skin peeling away, redness of the skin, fever, and blister formation over the last 48 hours. On examination, the child is irritable, lethargic and crying excessively. The condition is shown in the image given below. Which of the following is true regarding the toxin released by the causative agent in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Beta haemolysin doesn’t show hot or cold phenomenon

options.label: D
options.text: An exfoliative toxin is not involved in Ritters disease

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient present s to the physician complaining of cough for three weeks, chills, fever and extreme weight loss. The blood sample was sent to the laboratory for testing. In the laboratory, an interferon-gamma release assay was used for the diagnosis. Which of the following statements regarding the Interferon-gamma release assays used for the diagnosis is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: 1st generation Quantiferon-TB does not use ESAT-6

options.label: B
options.text: 2nd generation Quantiferon-TB (gold) used ESAT-6 and CFP-10

options.label: C
options.text: These tests can distinguish between M. tuberculosis and M. Bovis

options.label: D
options.text: None of the non-tubercular mycobacteria gives a positive reaction with this test

questions.correct_answer: B. 2nd generation Quantiferon-TB (gold) used ESAT-6 and CFP-10

questions.text: A 33-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of fever, diarrhea, rose spots on his back, stomach pain and vomiting for 1 week. He has no history of any chronic illnesses. He is vitally stable, and the remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The growth obtained on the sample culture is shown in the image below. Choose the right statement on the basis of given media and colony characteristics.

options.label: A
options.text: Jet black-coloured colonies of S. typhi on Wilson Blair's agar.

options.label: B
options.text: Jet black-coloured colonies of S. typhi on Deoxycholate citrate agar (DCA).

options.label: C
options.text: Brown black-coloured colonies of S. typhi on Wilson Blair's agar.

options.label: D
options.text: Brown black coloured colonies of S. paratyphi A on Wilson Blair's agar

questions.correct_answer: A. Jet black-coloured colonies of S. typhi on Wilson Blair's agar.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of being tired all the time and having a slight fever for two weeks. He recently returned from a trip to Las Vegas, where he indulged in some of the infamous nightlife. He has no history of any chronic illnesses. The patient is vitally stable and his physical examination is unremarkable except for a macular rash over his trunk and on the palms of his hands. There are no lesions or ulcers on the penis. Which of the following organism is causing the patient's current pathology?

A 30 years old male presented with discrete hypopigmented macules on his upper back. The patient works as a labourer in a steel mill. On examination of skin scrapings with 10% KOH under a microscope, spaghetti and meatball appearances were seen. What is the probable diagnosis?

A 26-year-old male from a rural village with a history of swimming in the pond presents to the physician with complaints of fever, headache, confusion and vomiting. On further examination, the physician suspected a parasitic infection. He sent the sample for culture to identify the causative organism. Which selective medium is most likely to be used for isolating the organism in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Nutrient agar rich with E. coli

questions.correct_answer: C. Non-Nutrient agar with E. coli

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to OPD with a complaint of abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting for the last two days. She also reports headaches, insomnia and generalised weakness. His examination reveals a high blood pressure of 160/110mmHg with a pulse rate of 90 beats per minute. On examination, hepatomegaly is noticed. Additionally, her vitamin B-12 levels are low. The clinical diagnosis of malignant hydatid disease is made. Which of the following is true about malignant hydatid disease in the patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Hydatid disease in the immunocompromised host

questions.text: A 5-month-old child is brought to the hospital by his mother with complaints of recurrent diarrhoea and fever. She is worried about admitting her child again this month. On complete physical examination, the baby has a whitish plaque in the mouth, and diaper area rashes look like a fungal infection. The patient is advised to go for molecular genetic testing and the results of which showed an Adenosine deaminase (ADA) enzyme deficiency. This deficiency is associated with which of the following condition?
In which phase of bacterial growth does sporulation occur?

A 25-year-old female complains of recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge, and bilateral nasal blockage for one year. She has had a history of asthma and allergy since childhood. On examination, multiple ethmoidal polyps are noted with mucosal thickening and secretions are impacted in both nasal cavities. A biopsy is taken, and the material is cultured, which shows the growth of many hyphae with dichotomous branching, typically at 45 degrees. Which of the following is the most likely responsible organism for causing the disease?

As part of the autopsy of the body of a young man, the doctor had an X-ray done to determine the ossification status of the bone to narrow down on the age. The following image was the x-ray of the hip joint done postmortem. He notices that the center for the head, greater and lesser trochanter of the femur appeared but has not fused. The triradiate cartilage has not obliterated . Which age range will the doctor interpret the victim to be of, on viewing below X-Ray?

questions.text: A Person was admitted with diarrhoea, vomiting, low-grade fever, breathlessness, abdominal and lower limb pain and later became semiconscious, cyanotic, tachypneic, tachycardic and hypotensive and died. Autopsy finding revealed inflamed intestines with "rice-water" like contents and "red-velvety appearance" stomach mucosa. What is the causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Differentiation : Arsenic poisoning and cholera

S.No.

Feature

Arsenic poisoning

Cholera

1.

Pain in throat

Before vomiting

After vomiting

2.

Vomiting and purging

Purging follows vomiting

Vomiting follows purging

3.

Vomitus

Contains mucus, bile and blood

Watery, without mucus, bile or blood

4.

A 40-year-old male visited to the hospital for permanent sterilization operation. The physician explained him about vasectomy method. Which of the following is not true regarding ‘no scalpel’ vasectomy?

options.label: A
options.text: Special instruments are used to deliver the vas instead of cutting the skin

options.label: B
options.text: Scrotal skin is cut with LASER to expose the vas

options.label: C
options.text: The failure rate is the same as that of conventional vasectomy

options.label: D
options.text: It is a very popular method in China

questions.correct_answer: B. Scrotal skin is cut with LASER to expose the vas
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ No scalpel vasectomy (also called keyhole vasectomy or NSV) is a vasectomy procedure variant in which a sharp hemostat is used to puncture the scrotum to access the vas deferens instead of giving an incision as in conventional vasectomy. No cuts are made in no-scalpel vasectomy, but the skin is punctured. The failure rate is the same as that of conventional vasectomy. It is a very popular method in China. It is a daycare procedure. No stitches are made.
  • ➤ No scalpel vasectomy (also called keyhole vasectomy or NSV) is a vasectomy procedure variant in which a sharp hemostat is used to puncture the scrotum to access the vas deferens instead of giving an incision as in conventional vasectomy.
  • ➤ No cuts are made in no-scalpel vasectomy, but the skin is punctured.
  • ➤ The failure rate is the same as that of conventional vasectomy.
  • ➤ It is a very popular method in China.
  • ➤ It is a daycare procedure.
  • ➤ No stitches are made.
  • ➤ The NSV approach offers several benefits, including a lower risk for infection, bleeding, bruising, and pain. No scalpel vasectomy and conventional vasectomy are equally effective. Steps of no-scalpel vasectomy: By using the three-finger method on both sides, the vas deferens are isolated. Midway between the top of the testicles and the base of the penis is the best location for needle insertion. The vas is isolated and encircled with the ringed clamp. The scrotal skin is punctured, the tissues are spread out, and the vas deferens are pierced to deliver it outside the scrotum using the dissecting forceps. The vas deferens is subsequently blocked.
  • ➤ The NSV approach offers several benefits, including a lower risk for infection, bleeding, bruising, and pain.
  • ➤ No scalpel vasectomy and conventional vasectomy are equally effective.
  • ➤ Steps of no-scalpel vasectomy: By using the three-finger method on both sides, the vas deferens are isolated. Midway between the top of the testicles and the base of the penis is the best location for needle insertion. The vas is isolated and encircled with the ringed clamp. The scrotal skin is punctured, the tissues are spread out, and the vas deferens are pierced to deliver it outside the scrotum using the dissecting forceps. The vas deferens is subsequently blocked.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a 3-month history of 10kg weight loss despite an increased appetite. She also complains of anxiety, diarrhoea and amenorrhea. Examination reveals a fine tremor, brisk reflexes and a systolic murmur heard throughout the precordium. A urine pregnancy screen was negative. What is the most likely finding in examining the pulse?
questions.explanation:
Rhythm disorder characteristics

Rhythm

Causes

ECG Features

Atrial fibrillation

  • Mitral valve disorders
  • Myocardial infarction, hypertension, coronary artery disease, heart failure
  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
  • Digoxin toxicity
  • Post cardiac surgery
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Electrolyte abnormalities
  • Venous thromboembolism
  • Obesity
  • Diabetes
  • Obstructive sleep apnoea
  • Pneumonia
  • Alcohol excess
  • Caffeine
  • QRS width: <120 milliseconds
  • Atrial rate is 350-400 beats per minute but ventricular rate is variable
  • Heart rate is irregular
  • Absent P-waves  

Atrial flutter

  • Underlying cardiac disorder, mitral or tricuspid  valve disease
  • Cor pulmonale
  • Post-myocardial infarction complication
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Excess alcohol
  • Post cardiac surgery
  • QRS width: <120 milliseconds
  • Atrial rate is 250-350 beats per minute, ventricular rate varies according to atrioventricular node conduction
  • Regular P-waves are typically absent with mainly flutter or saw tooth waves

Ventricular tachycardia

  • Acute myocardial infarction
  • Chronic ischaemia
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Electrolyte abnormalities
  • Congenital problems
  • Drugs (antiarrhythmic, digoxin)
  • Idiopathic/unknown
  • Regular rhythm
  • Wide QRS:>120 milliseconds
  • Monomorphic, with all QRS complexes being the same shape

Torsades de pointers

  • Amiodarone
  • Tricyclic antidepressants
  • Low magnesium or potassium
  • Congenital problems
  • Excess alcohol
  • Malnourishment
  • QT – Prolonging medications
  • Regular rhythm
  • Wide QRS: >120 milliseconds
  • Polymorphic, with varying shape and size QRS complexes

A 58-year-old male was diagnosed with chronic myeloid leukaemia after an incidental finding of leukocytosis last year. He was treated with imatinib , and the treatment was changed to nilotinib because of progressive leukocytosis. On follow-up, investigations revealed worsening of leukocytosis & thrombocytopenia. His peripheral blood showed >30% blasts with promyelocytes . What is the most effective treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Accelerated phase of CML

The patient is considered to be in accelerated phase if any of the following are true:

  • The blood samples have 15% or more but fewer than 30% blasts.
  • Basophils make up 20% or more of the blood cells.
  • Blasts and promyelocytes combined makeup 30% or more of the blood.
  • Very low platelet counts (100 x 1,000/cubic meter or less) that are not caused by treatment.
  • New chromosomes changes in the leukaemic cells with the Philadelphia chromosomes

Treatment options are as follows:

  • Patients who present with or evolve to blastic phase, combinations of chemotherapy and Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitors (TKI) should be used to induce remission, followed by allogeneic stem cell transplantation as soon as possible.
  • Patients who evolve from chronic to accelerated phase or patients with de novo accelerated-phase CML may do well with long-term TKI therapy; the timing of allogeneic stem cell transplantation depends on their optimal response to TKI (achievement of complete cytogenetic response).
  • The most effective is stem cell transplantation.

Patient’s Score

Questions

3

  

The examiner names three unrelated objects clearly and slowly, then the instructor asks the patient to name all three of them. The patient’s response is used for scoring. The examiner repeats them until patient learns all of them, if possible

Show the patient two simple objects, such as a wristwatch and a pencil, and ask the patient to name them.

1

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient with a history of schizophrenia has been taking a second-generation antipsychotic medication for the past month. She presents to the clinic with complaints of an intense inner restlessness and an inability to sit still. The restlessness is distressing and is affecting her daily activities. On examination, the patient is observed constantly shifting in her chair, crossing and uncrossing her legs, and frequently changing her position. She describes a strong urge to keep moving and feels unable to find relief. What is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Akathisia

Characteristics

Definition

Restlessness and an overwhelming urge to keep moving

Subjective signs

Patient reports feeling restless

Objective signs

Others observe specific motor behaviors

Motor behaviors

- Rocking motion
 

- Placing around
 

- Rapid alteration of sitting and standing

Treatment

- Beta blockers (e.g., Propranolol)
 

- Anticholinergics
 

- Benzodiazepines
 

- Reducing antipsychotic drugs
 

- Changing drug to atypical/low-potency typical antipsychotics

questions.text: A previously healthy 11-year-old boy presents to the emergency room with a 3-day history of nausea, anorexia , weakness, abdominal pain, and six episodes of vomiting associated with loose stools . A 15-year-old boy is brought to the primary rural health centre when he slipped from the roof of the house and fell onto a trishula fixed on the top of a small temple next to the house. The trishula entered the back near the renal fossa, traversed the abdomen, and exited through the anterior abdominal wall . The people around there dismantled the trishula from the top of the temple while it remained in situ. Due to the rural setup and poor communication, the ambulance took about 2 hours to reach there . The boy is conscious and in extreme pain . His blood pressure is 150/60mmHg, and his heart rate is 130 beats per minute. questions.text: A 74-year-old woman was hospitalized because of microcytic anemia, weight loss, anorexia, and vomiting. A 68-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease. Medications include insulin, metoprolol, and atorvastatin. Physical examination shows pitting oedema of both ankles. Serum creatinine concentration is 4.5 mg/dL. Donor kidney transplantation is planned by the physician . The kidney to be transplanted has to be stored at a temperature between 0-5° C and flushed with University of Wisconsin solution . What is the rationale behind storing kidneys at low temperatures?

options.text: Oxygen is more soluble in cold solutions and provides a continuous supply for energy metabolism

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Hypothermia diminishes energy requirements and allows the limited energy reserve to keep the organ alive

options.label: D
options.text: It slows down metabolism and the enzymatic processes that would destroy the cell

questions.text: What factor is accountable for transforming the gonad into testes, leading to the development of a male?
Review the following hysterosalpingogram and provide the appropriate diagnosis.
questions.explanation:
Complication Description
Infertility A unicornuate uterus may be associated with reduced fertility due to a smaller uterine cavity and limited space for a developing fetus.
Miscarriages Women with a unicornuate uterus have a higher risk of miscarriages, especially in pregnancies that occur in the unicornuate horn.
Ectopic Pregnancy The risk of ectopic pregnancies is increased in women with a unicornuate uterus, as fertilized eggs can implant in the nonfunctional horn.
Preterm Labor Pregnancies in a unicornuate uterus are at a higher risk of preterm labor and premature birth due to limited space for fetal growth.
Malpresentation Fetal malpresentation, such as breech position, is more common in pregnancies with a unicornuate uterus.
Renal Anomalies Some women with a unicornuate uterus may have associated kidney abnormalities, as these structures develop from the same embryonic system.
Uterine Rupture In rare cases, a unicornuate uterus may be prone to rupture during labor, which can be life-threatening for both the mother and baby.
Cervical Incompetence Women with a unicornuate uterus may have a higher risk of cervical incompetence, which can lead to preterm labor and pregnancy loss.

Which of the following umbilical artery Doppler findings is the most significant indication for termination of the pregnancy?

A 10-year-old boy presents in the emergency department with complaints of blood in urine, lower abdominal pain, and diarrhoea for 2 days. There is no history of decreased urine output. On examination, the patient's vitals are normal except for having tachycardia (102 beats/minute). He is mildly dehydrated and has evidence of dermatitis herpetiformis . Urine analysis shows evidence of gross haematuria. C3 levels are normal, and peripheral smear examination also shows no remarkable findings. Wh ich of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 7-year-old child presented to the emergency department with jerky repetitive movements of limbs for 10 minutes. He is stabilized and admitted from detention. On further evaluation, it is revealed that he has a developmental delay . His mother gives a history of tonic-clonic seizures a few times before . An EEG shows polyspike bursts while sleeping and slow waves while awakened . Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?

A 3-month-old infant presents in a paediatric clinic with inspiratory noises since 1 month; the noises are inspiratory and are increased when the baby is lying down, sleeping, and before or after feeding. According to his mother, he has no difficulty feeding. On examination, the child is of normal height and weight with a normal cry and mild tachypnea; the noise is inspiratory and increases when the baby is placed supine; the nasal pathway is clear; and there are no nasal secretions present. His laryngoscopy showed the following picture: What is the most probable diagnosis?

A 5-year-old girl always had to wear warm socks, even in the summer season. On physical examination, it was noticed that she had high blood pressure and that her femoral pulse was weak as compared to radial and carotid pulse; chest radiography showed a 'figure of 3' appearance and notching of the inferior margin of her ribs. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?

Establish a diagnosis for a child with petechiae, splenomegaly, hemoglobin level of 8 g/dL, platelet count of 50,000/µL, WBC count of 30,000/µL with 60% blast s, and a bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellular marrow with a high percentage of myeloblasts that are positive for myeloperoxidase on cytochemical staining.

A 20-day-old baby presents to the emergency department with symptoms of hypotonia, weak arms, uncontrolled clumsy movements, muscle spasms, and tremors. Further examination reveals the diagnosis of bilirubin encephalopathy in the neonate. Which type of palsy is seen as a sequel to bilirubin encephalopathy in this patient?
questions.explanation:
CEREBRAL PALSY AREA OF THE BRAIN INVOLVED
Spastic diplegia periventricular area (PVL – periventricular leukomalacia/ PVHI- Periventricular hemorrhagic infarct)
Spastic quadriplegia Multicystic encephalopathy ; Parasagittal brain injury
Spastic hemiplegia MCA territory infarct
Dyskinetic/Extrapyramidal cerebral palsy Basal ganglia (neonatal jaundice/kernicterus)
Hypotonic Cerebellar lesion

questions.text: During the 1950s, thalidomide, a medication utilized in Germany for hyperemesis gravidarum , led to the birth defect known as phocomelia in the offspring of mothers who used it. Presently, phocomelia is a seldom-occurring bone disorder due to the ban on the drug in certain countries. Which bones are typically impacted by phocomelia?

A 6-month-old male infant is brought to the paediatric outpatient department by his mother due to excessive sleepiness for 1 week . It is associated with constipation for 2 weeks . He was delivered at term via normal vaginal delivery and had no medical check-ups afterwards. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a lethargic infant with periorbital puffiness, a large tongue, and an umbilical hernia . Which of the following test s will help diagnose the patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
TSH

T4

Thyroid dyshormonogenesis

ELEVATED

LOW

Thyroid dysgenesis

ELEVATED

LOW

Central hypothyroidism

LOW

LOW

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a known history of uncontrolled diabetes presents to the physician with complaints of severe persistent earache, greenish discharge from the ear, and headache for 3 months. He is otherwise vitally stable and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. Otoscopy reveals granulation tissue at the cartilage bone of the external auditory canal. Which of the following dehiscence in the external auditory canal leads to the spread of infection in this case?

A 62-year-old judge presents to the physician complaining of the subtle weakness of his left lower face that he first noted while shaving. Two months later, he noted that he could no longer close his left eyelid fully and had increasing weakness in the remainder of his left face. Which of the following is the narrowest nerve segment involved in the patient's pathology?

A 40-year-old woman neuro-fibromatosis II patient comes to the E.N.T. department with a 3-week history of intermittent episodes of dizziness. The episodes last for hours and are characterized by the sensation that the room is spinning. The patient also reports that she has started using her cell phone with her left ear because she hears better on that side. She has experienced intermittent ringing and fullness in her right ear. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 76/min, respiration is 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/76 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There is horizontal nystagmus to the right. M.R.I. revealed the below image. Which of the following audio-metric test is a reliable indicator in this patient?

A 12-year-old male presents to the ENT department with a complaint of recurrent epistaxis. On extensive examination and workup, he is diagnosed with a case of hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia. Which of the following is the treatment of choice in recurrent epistaxis in this patient?

A 10-year-old boy presents to the ENT outpatient department due to bilateral earaches and impaired hearing for 1 week. His mother reports that the child has had recurrent upper respiratory tract infections for a few months . The patient has the following features on physical examination, along with amber-coloured fluid behind the tympanic membranes bilaterally. Surgical excision is planned for this patient’s disease. Which of the following is not a complication of the surgery performed on this patient?
questions.explanation:
Aspect Description
Procedure Adenoidectomy is a surgical procedure to remove the adenoids, which are lymphoid tissue located at the back of the nasal cavity.
Indication Adenoidectomy is performed to alleviate symptoms and conditions such as:
  - Recurrent or chronic adenoiditis (inflammation of the adenoids).
  - Nasal obstruction or airway blockage due to enlarged adenoids.
  - Chronic or recurrent sinusitis.
  - Ear infections or fluid in the middle ear (otitis media) related to adenoid enlargement.
Side Effects and Complications While Adenoidectomy is generally safe, there are potential side effects and complications that may occur, including:
  - Sore throat and discomfort after surgery.
  - Temporary changes in speech, such as hyponasal speech.
  - Transient nasal regurgitation of fluids or food due to changes in the soft palate function (velopharyngeal insufficiency).
  - Transient nasal bleeding (epistaxis).
  - Swelling around the Eustachian tube opening, causing transient hearing issues or ear discomfort.
  - Rarely, infection or bleeding at the surgical site.
  - Very rarely, complications like velopharyngeal insufficiency or Grisel syndrome (abnormal cervical spine movement) may occur.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the ENT clinic by her parents with the complaint of abnormally muffled voice since birth. She was born full term and has normally achieved her developmental milestones. On examination, there is no sign of respiratory distress. Laryngoscopy reveals a thin membrane with a concave posterior border between the vocal cords. Which of the following is the most common site of the above pathology?

A 50-year-old male presents to the ENT outpatient department with hoarseness of voice for the last two days. Two weeks ago, he was admitted to the intensive care unit due to a COVID-19 infection complicated by respiratory failure. He underwent endotracheal intubation and was kept on mechanical ventilation. On a laryngoscopy, he is found to have the following lesion: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old male presents to the ENT clinic with complaints of recurrent ear discharge from his left ear for the past 6 months. He reports a foul-smelling, yellowish-green discharge with occasional bloodstains. He also complains of mild hearing loss in the affected ear. On examination, the left ear canal shows a central perforation of the tympanic membrane with granulation tissue. There are no signs of active infection or inflammation in the ear. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Topic Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM)
Definition Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM) is a long-standing middle ear infection characterized by a persistent, recurrent, and sometimes foul-smelling ear discharge due to a perforation in the tympanic membrane.
Causes - Incomplete resolution of acute otitis media (ear infection).
  - Prolonged or untreated ear infections.
  - Persistent Eustachian tube dysfunction.
  - Trauma to the eardrum.
Signs and Symptoms - Recurrent ear discharge, which may be purulent and foul-smelling.
  - Hearing loss, which can vary in severity.
  - Ear pain or discomfort (less common).
  - Tinnitus (ringing in the ears).
  - Itching or irritation in the ear canal.
Complications - Cholesteatoma: An abnormal growth of skin in the middle ear or mastoid.
  - Bone erosion: Destruction of the ossicles or other middle ear structures.
  - Mastoiditis: Infection and inflammation of the mastoid bone.
Diagnosis - Otoscopic examination: To visualize the tympanic membrane and ear canal for perforation and discharge.
  - Audiometry: To assess hearing loss and degree of hearing impairment.
  - Culture and sensitivity testing: To identify the causative bacteria and guide antibiotic treatment.
  - High-resolution CT scan (temporal bone): To evaluate the middle ear and mastoid for complications like cholesteatoma or bone erosion.
Treatment - Antibiotics: To treat and prevent infection. Topical antibiotics are often used in ear drop form.
  - Ear cleaning and aural toileting: To remove debris and discharge from the ear canal.
  - Surgery: In cases of severe complications or persistent infections, surgical intervention may be necessary. Procedures include tympanoplasty (reconstruction of the tympanic membrane), mastoidectomy (removal of infected mastoid air cells), or cholesteatoma removal.
Prevention - Prompt and appropriate treatment of acute otitis media to prevent its progression to chronic infection.

questions.text: Children in the school-going age (6-14 years) represent over 25 % of the population in developing countries. The proximity between the teacher and the students makes the "school teacher" the most appropriate "primary screener" for the vision screening programme among school children. Which of the following do the primary screeners use as the visual cut-off for referral to the nearest primary health care centre ?

A 24-year-old male patient presented to the accident and emergency department with a gunshot wound in the right side of his cheek caused by a bullet fired from an air gun half an hour ago. He is vitally stable, oriented to time, place and person, and has minimal blood loss. After initial resuscitation, a CT scan was done, which showed a foreign body located on the right side of the skull. It is determined that the pellet penetrated the anterior and posterior walls of the maxillary sinus without any noticeable injury to the blood vessels or nerve damage. Injury to which of the following structures can cause damage to lacrimal secretion in this patient?

A forty-six-year-old patient presents to your clinic with the complaint of visual difficulties in his right eye. He was recently diagnosed with a cataract in his right eye and was operated on for it with the placement of an intraocular lens. Eye examinations are performed. When the patient is asked to look from side to side, a pendulum motion resembling the action of a windshield wiper is noted. What is the cause of the patient’s condition?

A patient has primary open-angle glaucoma in his right eye. His visual acuity was 10/90; despite being on timolol, pilocarpine, and acetazolamide, the IOP remains 20 to 24mmhg. A subsequent visual field test showed further field loss progression in this eye. Which one of the following is the best treatment option for this patient?

A 50-year- old male presents in the outpatient department with a complaint of headaches for the last 1 year. On further questioning, he reveals that he suffers headaches only while reading the daily newspaper in the morning. It is associated with eye strain and difficulty focusing on different words in the newspaper; therefore, he used to hold books and newspapers farther away to focus on those. There is no previous history of blurred vision or use of a corrective lens in his life. He is subsequently referred to an optometrist to evaluate his eye symptoms as a direct cause of headaches. He underwent an eye examination, including visual acuity, but it does not confirm the condition now, would be the next step?
questions.correct_answer: A. Refraction with a near addition

questions.text: An 11-year-old male patient presents with a gradual diminution of vision in his left eye for the past 6 months. Ocular examination reveals a vision of 6/60 in his left eye with no improvement. The vision in his right eye is normal, i.e, 6/6. On fundoscopy, his right eye is normal & left eye shows retinal detachment and subretinal exudation extending into the fovea and telangiectatic vessels . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Symptoms

Signs
  • Blurred
  • Photopsia
  • Floaters
  • Red eye effect
  • Leukocoria
  • Strabismus
  • Corneal edema
  • Iris neovascularization
  • Heterochromia

Stage 1

Retinal telangiectasias

Stage 2

Telangiectasias and exudation

      1. Extra foveal
      2. Foveal

Stage 3

Exudative retinal detachment

  1. Subtotal detachment
    1. Extra foveal
    2. Foveal
  2. Total retinal detachment

Stage 4

Total retinal detachment and glaucoma  

Stage 5

Advance end-stage disease

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the emergency department due to a sudden loss of vision in the right eye. It is associated with pain on eye movement. She had a history of acute disseminated encephalomyelitis 2 months ago, for which she was treated with oral prednisolone. On examination, she can only count fingers when seeing from the right eye (visual acuity). A positive afferent pupillary defect is also present. The ophthalmologist suspects optic neuritis. Which of the following is least likely to diagnose optic neuritis?

A 50-year-old male presents to his family physician with complaints of vertical diplopia . He further explains that he feels unsure while descending stairs . He can eliminate the double vision by tilting his head toward the opposite side . The patient is otherwise vitally stable and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. Which of the following extraocular muscles is responsible for ocular malalignment in this case?

A 24-year-old man visits the clinic with a complaint of multiple, small, pruritic, and discolored skin patches on his upper chest and back for the last three weeks. He has no chronic medical condition and takes no medications. On examination, multiple hypopigmented circular macules are found on his upper chest and back, which are arranged around the hair follicles. Fine scaling is also evident on the surface of these macules. Similar lesions appeared on his neck last summer and resolved with topical treatment. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study to obtain at this time?

options.label: B
options.text: Slit skin smear from discrete macules

questions.correct_answer: A. Potassium hydroxide preparation of scales

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presented during the summer with a 2-day history of a painful, itchy rash affecting his face and neck. He had been helping to clear his neighbor’s garden for the preceding fortnight. He had recently been found to have mild hypertension, treated with bendroflumethiazide. He was otherwise well. On examination, he had a confluent rash localized to his face and neck (see image) with associated periorbital edema. The remainder of the examination was normal. A presumptive diagnosis of allergic contact dermatitis was made, and patch testing was scheduled after the rash had settled. What is the most likely candidate allergen?

A 49-year-old female visits the clinic with a complaint of recurrent painful blisters over the oral mucosa and genital area for the past many months. She gives a history of a similar lesion in the past. A biopsy from the lesion shows a supra-basal split on histopathology and IgG deposits in immunofluorescence microscopy, as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40 years old woman presented to the clinic with a history of seizure episodes, spasticity, and lower limb weakness for the last 2 months. She also complains of hearing loss and unsteadiness while standing and walking. She needs to support herself against a wall to avoid falling. She has not had any recent injuries and has no history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an unsteady gait. She sways when asked to stand upright with her feet together. She cannot hear fingers rubbing next to her ears or repeat words whispered in her ears. MRI brain showed a 3-cm tumor in the right cerebellopontine angle and a 4.5-cm tumor in the left cerebellopontine angle. The condition was associated with the gene defect coding for protein merlin. The most typical neurological tumor associated with gene defect is?
questions.explanation:
Gene Chromosome Protein Features
NF 1 17 Neurofibromin
  • Cafe-au-lait-macules (CALM)
  • Axillary Freckling
  • Lisch nodules
  • Peripheral nerve sheath tumors (neurofibromas)
  • Optic pathway gliomas [OPGs] and brainstem gliomas [BSGs]
  • Skeletal abnormalities
NF 2 22 Merlin
  • Vestibular Schwannoma (Acoustic neuroma): Commonest neurological tumor- 90-95%-Bilateral VSs are pathognomonic
  • Giant Neurofibromas, Meningioma
  • Spinal ependymomas
